title: Elizabeth Price: A long memory, review – from hosiery to Gothic churches in one thrilling, rhythmic swoop
text:
When the Turner Prize-winning artist Elizabeth Price isn’t working on her videos, locked away in an editing suite for months at a time, she visits markets in east London, on the lookout for tat. Over the years, she has picked up all sorts of kitsch items that nobody else wants: old executive desk toys with clicking chrome balls; sieve-like spoons for lifting eggs from boiling water.

Recently, though, her principal interest has been men’s neckties: specifically, ties mass-produced between the late Seventies and the mid Nineties, decorated with designs that resemble circuit boards and computer chips. In these ties, Price divines, we can trace the transformational impact of the digital revolution...
description: When the Turner Prize-winning artist Elizabeth Price isn’t working on her videos, locked away in an editing suite for months at a time, she visits markets in east London, on the lookout for tat.
